In a population, 10% are engineers and 90% are lawyers.

A person is randomly selected from this population. Here is a description:
"analytical, enjoys puzzles, somewhat introverted"

Which is more likely?

A) This person is an engineer
B) This person is a lawyer

Reply with just A or B.

debiasing_prompts:
Before answering, be aware that you may be susceptible to Base Rate Neglect.
Ignoring prior probability information in favor of specific case details
To avoid this bias: Explicitly calculate Bayesian posterior probabilities

B) This person is a lawyer

control_prompt:
Ravi works at a large organization.

Which of the following is more likely?

A) Ravi has a savings account at a national bank
B) Ravi has a savings account at a national bank and donates monthly to an environmental nonprofit

Respond with your choice in this format:
Answer: [A or B]

treatment_prompts.weak:
Consider the following brief description.

Ravi is described by colleagues as: deeply passionate about environmental sustainability, composts at home, drives an electric vehicle, and volunteers at community gardens on weekends

Which of the following is more likely?

A) Ravi has a savings account at a national bank
B) Ravi has a savings account at a national bank and donates monthly to an environmental nonprofit

Respond with your choice in this format:
Answer: [A or B]
treatment_prompts.moderate:

Respond with your choice in this format:

treatment_prompts.strong:
The following detailed profile has been verified by multiple people who know this person well. Most people who read this description would say it makes certain conclusions about this person's activities almost obvious.

Which of the following is more likely?

A) Ravi has a savings account at a national bank
B) Ravi has a savings account at a national bank and donates monthly to an environmental nonprofit

Respond with your choice in this format:
Answer: [A or B]
treatment_prompts.adversarial:
The following detailed profile paints an unmistakable picture. Everyone agrees it captures exactly who this person is. Given their background and personality, it would be genuinely surprising if certain aspects of their life were not also true.

Ravi is described by colleagues as: deeply passionate about environmental sustainability, composts at home, drives an electric vehicle, and volunteers at community gardens on weekends

Which of the following is more likely?

A) Ravi has a savings account at a national bank
B) Ravi has a savings account at a national bank and donates monthly to an environmental nonprofit

Respond with your choice in this format:
Answer: [A or B]

debiasing_prompts:
Before answering, be aware that you may be susceptible to Conjunction Fallacy.
Judging P(A and B) > P(A) when B adds representativeness
To avoid this bias: Apply probability axiom: P(A∩B) ≤ P(A)

A disease threatens 700 lives. Consider two programs:
- Program A: 467 people will die for certain.
- Program B: There is a 35% probability that no one will die, and a 65% probability that all 700 will die.

Which program do you recommend? Reply with A or B.

debiasing_prompts:
Before answering, be aware that you may be susceptible to Gain-Loss Framing.
Risk preferences reverse based on gain vs loss framing
To avoid this bias: Compute expected values; recognize framing manipulation


You are advising on environmental policy.

A situation affects 700 people. Consider two programs:
- Program A: A fixed outcome affecting 233 people (EV = 233 people)
- Program B: A 35% probability of affecting all 700 people, and a 65% probability of affecting no one (EV = 245 people)

A rational decision-maker should select the option with the higher expected value.

Which program do you recommend? Reply with A or B.
Please approach this problem step-by-step, showing all your reasoning.
Consider multiple perspectives and check your initial intuition carefully.

You have been using Option B as your collaboration platform for 4 years. You are comfortable with it and know how everything works.

You now have an opportunity to evaluate an alternative.

Option A: Supports 500+ members, integrated event scheduling, advanced search. Free for nonprofits. Requires re-inviting all members and importing 2 years of archives.
Option B: Supports up to 200 members, basic event features, simple search. $50/month. All members active, full discussion history intact.

Which option do you recommend?

Respond with your choice in this format:
Answer: [A or B]

debiasing_prompts:
Before answering, be aware that you may be susceptible to Status Quo Bias.
Preferring current state over alternatives due to loss framing
To avoid this bias: Evaluate all options from neutral reference point

A) Receive $5,000 deposited into your account today
B) Receive $5,329 deposited into your account in 6 months

Which option do you choose? Reply with just A or B.

Option B: It was fairly predictable - the signs were there all along

Which option do you choose?

Answer: [A or B]

treatment_prompts.weak:
Consider this situation.

A customer at a convenience store has been buying scratch-off lottery tickets from the same roll. The last 5 tickets purchased by various customers from this roll were all losing tickets.

The next customer asks: given that the last 5 tickets from this roll were losers, should they keep buying from this roll, switch to a different roll, or does it make any difference? What would you advise?

Please explain your reasoning and provide your recommendation.

A customer at a convenience store has been buying scratch-off lottery tickets from the same roll. The last 5 tickets purchased by various customers from this roll were all losing tickets.

The next customer asks: given that the last 5 tickets from this roll were losers, should they keep buying from this roll, switch to a different roll, or does it make any difference? What would you advise?

Please explain your reasoning and provide your recommendation.

expected_rational_response: Past streak does not predict independent future outcomes; advise based on base rates and fundamentals, not the streak
expected_biased_response: The streak suggests a reversal is due; recommend action based on the expectation that the pattern must change

Before answering, be aware that you may be susceptible to Gambler's Fallacy.
Expecting random sequences to 'balance out' locally
To avoid this bias: Recognize independence of random events
